dt: {bc}a return on an investment equal to the original capital outlay
{bc}the period of time elapsed before an investment is recouped

shortdef: a return on an investment equal to the original capital outlay; also : the period of time elapsed before an investment is recouped

dt: {bc}to make due return to for services rendered or property delivered

dt.t: {it}paid{/it} the pizza deliverer
You couldn't {wi}pay{/wi} me to do that.
{it}paid{/it} a teenager to mow his lawn

dt: {bc}to give in return for goods or service

dt.t: {wi}pay{/wi} wages
{wi}pay{/wi} a bill

dt: {bc}to make a disposal or transfer of (money)

dt.t: {it}paid{/it} a few dollars weekly into a savings account

dt: {bc}to give or forfeit in {d_link|expiation|expiation} or retribution

dt.t: {wi}pay{/wi} the penalty
His trouble was well {it}paid{/it} in the end.
{wi}pay{/wi} them back

dt: {bc}to give, offer, or make freely or as fitting

dt.t: {wi}pay{/wi} attention
{wi}pay{/wi} your respects
it {wi}pays{/wi} you to stay open
an investment {wi}paying{/wi} five percent

dt: {bc}to slacken (something, such as a rope) and allow to run out

dt.t: {it}paid{/it} out the rope as it jerked taut
I'll {wi}pay{/wi} when I have the money.

dt: {bc}to be worth the expense or effort

dt.t: crime doesn't {wi}pay{/wi}

dt: {bc}to suffer the consequences of an act

dt.t: He {it}paid{/it} for his crime.

dt: {bc}to earn a right or position through experience, suffering, or hard work

dt.t: He's {it}paid his dues{/it} and deserves a promotion.
She took a part-time job to {it}pay her own way{/it} through college.
You have to do what they say because they are {it}paying the piper{/it}.
I found the perfect dress, but I had to {it}pay through the nose{/it} for it.

pt: {sc}pay{/sc} {sc}compensate{/sc} {sc}remunerate{/sc} {sc}satisfy{/sc} {sc}reimburse{/sc} {sc}indemnify{/sc} {sc}repay{/sc} {sc}recompense{/sc} mean to give money or its equivalent in return for something. {sc}pay{/sc} implies the discharge of an obligation incurred.
{sc}compensate{/sc} implies a making up for services rendered.

pt.t: an attorney well {it}compensated{/it} for her services

pt: {sc}remunerate{/sc} clearly suggests paying for services rendered and may extend to payment that is generous or not contracted for.
{sc}satisfy{/sc} implies paying a person what is required by law.

pt.t: all creditors will be {it}satisfied{/it} in full

pt: {sc}reimburse{/sc} implies a return of money that has been spent for another's benefit.
{sc}indemnify{/sc} implies making good a loss suffered through accident, disaster, warfare.

pt.t: {it}indemnified{/it} the families of the dead miners

pt: {sc}repay{/sc} stresses paying back an equivalent in kind or amount.
{sc}recompense{/sc} suggests due return in amends, friendly repayment, or reward.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}paier{/it}, from Latin {it}pacare{/it} to pacify, from {it}pac-, pax{/it} peace
shortdef: to make due return to for services rendered or property delivered
to give in return for goods or service

dt: {bc}a time for punishment for something that was done in the past

dt.t: You've ruined my life, and now it's {it}payback time{/it}.

shortdef: a time for punishment for something that was done in the past
